comments.author: David Gardner

comments.text:
You also have to remember when this movie was made. At the time there was 
no way an American film company could've gotten a Russian military plane. 
Same goes for the "Mi-24 Hind" that was  used in the Red Dawn movie and the 
third Rambo film.

Thought everyone knew those weren't actual MiGs, but F5 Tigers.
comments.author: Keihryon

comments.text:
+David Gardner

The T-38 and the F-5 are not the same aircraft. The F-5 was borne out of 
the T-38's linage, but the F-5 had more powerful engine (particularly with 
the F-5E/F Tiger II), a beefier structure, and had(has) hard points for 
weapons and external fuel. The F-5 (and the twin seat F-5B/F) had a 
different cockpit layout too. The T-38 can be armed with a light/small 
load, but that is only mainly of small training munitions.
comments.author: ironroad

comments.text:
Soon the QF-16 will replace aggressor aircraft. Also the MiG-28s were 
literally repainted F-5s into "North Korean" colors...
comments.author: AWC

comments.text:
They also use F-16N and F/A-18s both painted in different schemes to what 
we use.  Go to google earth, find Naval Air Station Falon (East of Reno, NV 
by about 2 hours drive), zoom in on the tarmac and you can see the 
aggressor aircraft and their different camo schemes they use.
comments.author: Clay Ronso

comments.text:
It is true that the planes were either F-5s or T-38s (which are virtually 
the same jet, just equipped differently). They were obviously not MIGs or 
F-1s, totally not the same as the F-5. I knew this because I was in the Air 
Force at the time the movie came out.
comments.author: David Gardner

comments.text:
+gargouenzene The USAF used F-5s for OPFOR at Nellis AFB at this time 
period, while the Navy used A-4s at Top Gun. The AF and Navy have today 
switched to F-16s for this job (the AF also uses a squadron of F-15s for 
this job).
comments.author: Matthew Lu

comments.text:
F-5s have been used for Migs for the first and last dogfights. A-4s have 
been used at Miramar.
comments.author: gargouenzene

comments.text:
Although differential pressure is a contributor in "lift," it doesn't 
actually produce the majority of it. In fact it's quite minor really. It's 
more to do with the angular position of the wing, as it's tilted backward, 
air hitting it from the front becomes deflected downward, resulting in an 
opposing force of pushing the wing upward. However, since the wing is 
angled, and can't deflect all the air straight down, it produces another 
force, in reverse. This is drag. Having a high lift to drag ratio, with the 
right air deflection angle, and aircraft velocity is necessary for lift. 
Differential pressure, less so.﻿

comments.text:
+Richard +gargouenzene 
Actually, its nothing so sinister. During the mid 80s, VF-111 was based 
at NAS Miramar, at the West end of Hangar 3. The nickname for the squadron 
was the "Sundowners" and the artwork on Sundowns flight helmet was a 
replica of tail-art used by that squadron. 

 
https://www.google.com/search?q=vf-111&safe=off&rlz=1T4GUEA_enUS574US574&tbm=isch&tbo=u&source=univ&sa=X&ei=j7aLVO-1OIuAygTwx4H4Cw&ved=0CCwQsAQ&biw=1182&bih=744#safe=off&tbm=isch&q=vf-111+f-14&revid=995631533&facrc=_&imgdii=_&imgrc=-sjVP8h3mvJ8cM%253A%3BdIFkWN1YvzJzsM%3Bhttp%253A%252F%252Fflyawaysimulation.com%252Fmedia%252Fimages3%252Fimages%252Fgrumman-F-14D-tomcat-VF-111-repaint-fsx1.jpg%3Bhttp%253A%252F%252Fflyawaysimulation.com%252Fdownloads%252Ffiles%252F5092%252Ffsx-grumman-f-14d-tomcat-vf-111-repaint%252F%3B1440%3B900

comments.author: Rondu01

comments.text:
+stronzo861 i'll just explain it: it's a reference to how he'll lynch your 
ass outta the sky like he was white and you were a black guy in the wrong 
town past sun down. Its an inverted racial slur, and black people use 
racial slurs that were meant to demean them and invert them 'to their 
advantage' all the time. I mean, we've all heard crappy rap songs that do 
it. Regardless, they and the culture around them set a mandate: no one can 
use the word nigger and not be racist other than a black person, just like 
no one can use the word cracker and not be racist other than a white 
person. Since the call sign is on a black man's forehead, it's not racist 
if he gave himself that name. But we don't know this because the script, 
and nearly everything else about this film, was written by someone who's 
not black, nor is there any explanation behind the origin of his call sign 
or anything else about him. Is it all that important to me to discover the 
truth of whether it's racist or just ironic? Does it lessen the quality of 
the film or distract from the plot? Not at all. His part was so small and 
mostly insignificant because he wasn't in the film past sun down anyways.
comments.author: Richie Hicks

racist. Just trying to help you.

comments.author: Hermione Ziggeraut

comments.text:
+CognizantCheddar Your entire argument is a straw.  You are the one who 
said that the pilots looked caucasian therefore Soviets, hence I remended 
you of the planes themselves.  Stunt Pilot ethnicity and specific plane 
model availability are the two things that cannot be considered, since you 
foolishly brought one of these factors up, I checked you  with the other.
Let me school you on a few things
1--Wrong insignia to be the USSR, It's not like it was hard for a major 
movie to use the right national insignia or other war movies were not using 
actual soviet insignia to represent fictional soviet hardware.  YOU HAVE NO 
RESPONSE TO THIS
2--The country in question considered part of the Indian Ocean their 
"territorial waters".  That means they border on the fucking ocean retard, 
not a thousand miles away with non-aligned nations between them and the 
actual ocean.  Oh and a Soviet declaration of the Indian Ocean belonging to 
them would be an act of war itself.  That's like Canada trying to claim 
sovereignty over the fucking gulf of Mexico.  BASIC GEOGRAPHY DISAGREES 
WITH YOUR PREMISE, YOU HAVE NO RESPONSE.
3--The Russians did not have nor did they need French Exocet missiles, they 
had much better anti-ship missiles of their own design.  Many poor 
countries during the cold war bought hardware from Russia and then bought 
software and missiles from France since it was much, much better than 
export model Russian stuff.  USE OF FRENCH MISSILES DISQUALIFIES THIS 
ADVERSARY BEING THE USSR, YOU HAVE NO RESPONSE TO THIS.
.4--Soviet doctrine, just like American doctrine was about doing anything 
to avoid flagrantly attacking the other side's planes or ships in 
international waters, which could lead to major conflict or nuclear 
exchange.  Soviet pilots doing some shit like that would have been executed 
if they survived the fight and they know that.  FOR YOUR PREMISE TO BE 
TRUE, THE SOVIETS WOULD HAVE ALREADY LOST THEIR DAMN MINDS.
5--In both the Korean and Vietnam war, the absolute most advanced Russian 
fighters were sent to these client states to fight the west (Mig-15, and 
Mig-21 respectively), they were export models though.  HISTORY PROVES YOU 
WRONG, PART 1
6--During the Cold war, there were DOZENS of small actions like this 
between US or Soviet forces and some shitty little client state of the 
other, THAT'S WHY THEY CALLED IT THE COLD WAR, it was fought by small proxy 
wars all over the globe.  This action being a fictional Soviet client state 
fits in perfectly with what actually went on during the cold war.  HISTORY 
PROVES YOU WRONG, PART 2
7--"New" aircraft is a relatively flexible term, they are "new" to us 
because we hadn't seen them up close before.  During the Cold war, each 
side often had weapons systems operational for several years before the 
other side really knew much about them, in fact it was usually encountering 
export models of said equipment sent to client states that first contact 
with such weaponry was made.  Again, this fits perfectly with the story 
presented in Top Gun as the "first time anyone's been that close before".  
HISTORY PROVES YOU WRONG PART 3.

Seriously, are you retarded or are you 15 or something?  Rarely have I 
encountered a person who tries to speak with such authority about shit he 
OBVIOUSLY knows nothing about.
comments.author: 22steve5150

comments.text:
+22steve5150

The Soviet navy had a regular presence in the Indian Ocean, man. 

"and their 'mig-28's' were a bunch of black painted F-5 Freedom Fighters 
and T-38 Talons"

So?  We're talking about plot-context, not movie-prop reality.  The 
fictional MiG-28s were explicitly stated to be Russia's tip-top end model.  
Mikoyan didn't give their top-secret prototypes to mere allies.

You're grasping at straws, dude. Just man up and concede a point on the 
internet, wow.
comments.author: CognizantCheddar

comments.text:
+CognizantCheddar yet the air battles both at the beginning and end of the 
movie take place in the Indian ocean, and those Mig fighters would have had 
to have flown at least a thousand miles over other nation's airspace to 
even reach the Indian ocean and fight, yet the battle occurs with forces 
from a country that considers that part of the ocean their territorial 
waters.  THAT"S NOT THE USSR.
Also, they use French anti-ship missiles instead of Soviet anti-ship 
missiles, and France sure has hell never sold Exocets to Russia.  IT'S NOT 
THE USSR, The insignia on their aircraft and helmets also does not match 
1980's Soviet Insignia.  IT"S NOT THE USSR.  it is meant to be some shitty 
fictional Soviet client state that actually borders the Indian ocean.  Yes 
those pilots looked caucasian, and their "mig-28's" were a bunch of black 
painted F-5 Freedom Fighters and T-38 Talons.
comments.author: 22steve5150

comments.text:
+22steve5150

Except the pilots of those MiGs were Caucasian, bud.  I'm also pretty sure 
the lines they're heard chattering in one or two scenes is Slavic.

And while I should fact-check to be sure, I am 99% certain allied communist 
states like Cuba and Vietnam were *definitely not* sold cutting-edge MiGs, 
which the movie explicitly states they were (e.g. Cruise's character boasts 
of it to the love-interest in that intelligence meeting).  Even China was 
only ever sold dated or second-hand models.  And just lol @ the idea of 
nations like Angola, Afghanistan, and Mozambique getting any.

Those MiGs were obviously piloted by eastern Europeans, whoever they were.  
And set before the Soviet Union's collapse, that almost guarantees they 
were Soviets.

And by the way?  I had assumed everything I just posted would have gone 
without saying when I posted before.
comments.author: CognizantCheddar

comments.text:
+CognizantCheddar No, it doesn't work that way.  "Client state" does not 
mean "part of the USSR", nor does it even mean that the USSR would be 
obligated to defend such a nation if attacked.  These client states 
included Cuba, Vietnam, Angola, Afganistan, and Mozambique, none of whom 
was formally a part of the Soviet Union or even the Warsaw Pact.  The USA 
had an even bigger list of client states back then.
comments.author: 22steve5150

comments.text:
+22steve5150

"they were just one of their client states"

Which would make them Soviets.  Hence the 'union' in Soviet Union.
comments.author: CognizantCheddar

comments.text:

comments.text:
Yeah, Tony Scott used men's fashion photography of the time as visual 
reference for the actor's hairstyles and the infamous oiled volleyball 
scene. Real pilots cringed a lot watching the abundant technical 
inaccuracies and silliness in this film but hey it is a movie and it made 
being in the military cool again... One of the best recruitment periods for 
pilots ever after this film came out.
